title: A Short Note On Large Language Models

last_post.content: “A ‘poem’ is when an argument is so much itself that it can simply appear, and take a metrical form as an indication of its always-already having been present in the language, but just not organized into a poem yet. What the poet does is notice the concatenation of the geometric ‘fact’ of the poem’s possibility within a particular rhyme-and-meter space, and point that out.” https://vebaccount.substack.com/p/a-short-note-on-large-language-models

title: Scientists Have Created a New Type of Ice

last_post.content:
“It was one of those Friday afternoon experiments where you just do it and see what happens,” said Christoph Salzmann, a physical chemist at University College London.

They put regular ice and steel balls in a jar and cooled them to minus 200 degrees Celsius, shaking the container at about 20 times per second. You can see them doing it here:

https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/scientists-have-created-a-new-type-of-ice-180981579/

The new ice has a density of 1.06 grams/cm³.

(2/2)

StreetPass is a cool new browser extension that uses Mastodon's verification system in a clever way.

Mastodon users verify themselves by adding a custom link to their personal site. StreetPass lets you know when you've found one of these links, and adds them to your list. As you browse the web, StreetPass will build a list of Mastodon users that belong to the websites you visit.

I spoke with the creater @tvler about the project, 🧵 below.

Visit https://streetpass.social/ to try it yourself!

title: AI models spit out photos of real people and copyrighted images

last_post.content:
Popular image generation models can be prompted to produce identifiable photos of real people, potentially threatening their privacy, according to new research. The work also shows that these AI systems can be made to regurgitate exact copies of medical images and copyrighted work by artists. It’s a finding that could strengthen the case for artists who are currently suing AI companies for copyright violations. https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/02/03/1067786/ai-models-spit-out-photos-of-real-people-and-copyrighted-images/
#AI #copyright #Art #photography

In Every Layout, we wrote about The Stack. It’s a marriage of Heydon’s Lobotomised Owl selector and my method of managing Flow and Rhythm with CSS Custom Properties.

.stack > * + * {
margin-block-start: 1.5rem;
}

Let’s break the selector down: every direct sibling element of .stack has margin-block-start added to it. This is achieved by the Lobotomised Owl selector, but the > combinator is added to prevent margin being add

📢 In a recent report, Microsoft Digital Threat Analysis Center (DTAC) attributes a recent influence operation targeting French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo to an Iranian nation-state actor, NEPTUNIUM.

💧 In January, a hacker group known as "Holy Souls" claimed to have obtained the personal information of over 200,000 Charlie Hebdo customers. They released a sample of the data, which included full names, telephone numbers, and email and home addresses, putting subscribers at risk of targeting by extremist organizations.

🛡️ To help against these influence operations, DTAC also released their Influence Attribution Framework. This tool helps organizations understand, attribute, and mitigate the impact of these operations. 📢 In a recent report, Microsoft Digital Threat Analysis Center (DTAC) attributes a recent influence operation targeting French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo to an Iranian nation-state actor, NEPTUNIUM.

💧 In January, a hacker group known as "Holy Souls" claimed to have obtained the personal information of over 200,000 Charlie Hebdo customers. They released a sample of the data, which included full names, telephone numbers, and email and home addresses, putting subscribers at risk of targeting by extremist organizations.

What are examples of designs (in tech) that had an explicit goal to be good/useful well into the future? Say, at least 20+ years from the initial design?

Off the top of my head, some examples are https://danluu.com/dick-sites-alpha-axp-architecture.pdf, http://www.paulgraham.com/hundred.html, Perl 6 (Larry Wall says he was inspired by PG's 100-year language idea), and https://flarelang.sourceforge.net/goals.html.

I'm curious, if you look at the kinds of reasoning employed in design docs, etc., which classes of reasons have held up and which haven't.

title: Facebook secretly killed users batteries, worker claims in lawsuit

last_post.content: Firms like #Meta run thousands of A/B experiments on individuals every day, without consideration for transparency and consent requirements of #researchEthics. Some are innocuous, but there is no oversight on where they draw the line, particularly as they prize #tradeSecrets over disclosure. Furthermore, trade secrecy was never designed to trump or balance against ethical disclosure of experimentation—the warped framework no longer meets policy goals. https://nypost.com/2023/01/28/facebook-fires-worker-who-refused-to-do-negative-testing-awsuit/ #ABTesting

title: Real World Data Science - Why open science is ‘just good science in a digital era’

The White House Office of Science and Technology Policy has declared 2023 the Year of #OpenScience.
